title: Preparing Assisted Living Staff to Provider Palliative Care to Residents With Dementia: Palliative Care Education in Assisted Living for Dementia Care Providers (PCEAL-DCP)
description_brief: The palliative care education in assisted living for dementia care providers (PCEAL-DCP) is a 4-week intervention (once a week for 1.5 hours, a total of 6 hours) for licensed nurses, administrators and dementia care coordinators to improve quality of dementia care outcomes
description_detailed: This is a five-year cluster randomized trial (CRT) among 30 assisted living (AL) communities (k=30) and residents (N=450), staff (N=72) and family members (N=270) with a baseline, 3, and 6 months post-intervention follow-ups for residents, a baseline and 6-month follow-up for family and a pre- and post-test (one month), 3- and 6-month follow-up for staff and baseline AL facility information from administrators to examine dementia care outcomes.
explanation_target: Reason: The described intervention is a 4-week palliative care education program for assisted‑living staff (4 sessions × 1.5 hours) aimed at improving dementia care outcomes (advance care planning documentation, hospice use, staff self‑efficacy), not a pharmacologic agent — this fits a non‑therapeutic, behavioral training intervention. citeturn1search4turn1search0

Act: Key extracted details — intervention name: Palliative Care Education in Assisted Living for Dementia Care Providers (PCEAL‑DCP); format: behavioral palliative care training delivered by hospice nurses/social workers; design: cluster randomized trial in assisted living communities (planned sites/residents/staff/family follow‑ups); primary focus is supportive/palliative care outcomes rather than targeting Alzheimer’s pathology or cognition with a drug — no drug or placebo is involved. citeturn1search3turn1search0

Reflect: Given the intervention is educational/behavioral (training staff) and not a biologic or small‑molecule therapy, nor a cognitive enhancer or neuropsychiatric symptom drug, it does not match any of the four therapeutic categories — therefore classification = 'N/A'. This conclusion is supported by the study listings and the published feasibility pilot describing PCEAL as an educational/behavioral intervention. citeturn1search6turn1search4
